newsitem.title: FRANCE: EU extends sowing deadlines for Spain, Portugal.
newsitem.headline: EU extends sowing deadlines for Spain, Portugal.

text.p: The European Union has further extended sowing deadlines for maize and sunflower in Spain and Portugal, grain trade officials said on Friday.
The decision, adopted at Brussels grain talks on Thursday, gives farmers until June 21 to complete their sowings.

Sowing deadlines are mainly an administrative way of ensuring farmers register on time for EU area compensation under the Common Agricultural Policy, but have little real impact on the way they work in the fields, industry sources say.
Such deadlines can, however, influence the timing of major decisions on price-fixing and cereals trade on world markets.
Also on Thursday, the EU rejected bids for preferential discounts on import tariffs for maize imports to Spain and reduced the maximum volume eligible for such reductions.
The EU's cereals management committee cut the quota to 550,000 tonnes from 800,000 tonnes.
The grain trade officials said this was prompted by requests for import licences for cereal substitutes.
The rejected bids covered 681,676 tonnes and were for tariff reductions between 62.61 Ecus and 69.47 Ecus per tonne.

On June 11 the EU extended the sowing deadline for certain cereals and oilseeds in nine member states to May 31 or June 15, from mid-May, due to difficult climatic conditions, European Commission officials said.

The May 31 deadline applied to the following countries and crops: France (maize, sunflower seed, sorghum and soybeans), Austria (maize, soybeans), Britain (linseed), British farmers in the Orkney Islands (cereals), Germany (maize), Spain (sunflower seed) Portugal (maize, sorghum, sunflower seed).

The June 15 deadline applied to Finland (cereals, oilseeds, protein crops and linseed), Swedish farmers in several regions (cereals, oilseeds, protein crops and linseed), Italian farmers in Piedmont (maize, sorghum and soybeans).
